awd_titl_txt: Multiscale Analysis of Residual Stresses with Novel Non-Destructive and Destructive Approaches using Surface Displacement Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
Engineered materials and parts undergo severe mechanical and thermal loads during their development that result in the formation of internal residual stresses. Residual stresses (nominally force divided by area) are caused by internal forces that remain even after all external loads are removed. Despite the fact that residual stresses can reduce the service life considerably, comprehensive and practical methods to determine them without destroying the parts do not exist. Current non-destructive techniques allow their quantification on the surface of the parts only. Thus, development of new materials or manufacturing techniques can be greatly helped by a thorough estimation of residual stresses that might develop during the processes. For example, residual stresses are extremely prevalent in additively manufactured parts and strongly depend on process parameters in a complex way that are not understood well. This award supports fundamental research in inverse computational methods based on the mechanics of materials to estimate residual stresses in both non-destructive and destructive fashions from the measurement of forces and surface displacements. Advancement in residual stress analysis will promote both opportunistic use and mitigation in the development of new materials and manufacturing processes, which will greatly enhance automotive, aerospace, defense, and nuclear industries. The research team will also promote engineering and education through participation in the summer camp programs that will involve female and underrepresented high school students.

For the development of the non-destructive approach, surface displacements will be measured cost-effectively on varying part sizes using digital camera images to trace speckle patterns. Mechanics-based mathematical algorithms derived using adjoint equations will be implemented to infer residual stress distribution from these measurements. Validation on a 3D printed rubber like material will be conducted. For the development of the destructive approach, very thin sectioned samples will be retrieved from the polycrystalline specimens to relieve all residual stresses, with the implication that the thin slices will deform as a result. Subsequent loadings of the samples will be used to determine the heterogeneous, anisotropic granular microstructure of the material using mechanics-based mathematical models. Application of reverse deformation on the now known microstructure to retrieve the original configuration can then be used to predict the residual stresses in the given section of the material. The fundamental scientific issue underlying both approaches is: What are the minimum number of experimental data sets and deformation modes, i.e., experiments, required to uniquely map residual stresses?
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to develop non-destructive methods to know residual stresses in manufactured parts composed of metals or polymer plastics. Residual stresses exist in manufactured parts as a result of deformation, heat, loading, and other elements of the manufacturing process. Parts with significant residual stresses can prematurely fail through deformation, or catastrophic or fatigue fracture. Because of the emerging use and impact of additive manufacturing, these manufacturing methods have been a goal focus of this work. The intellectual impact of these goals includes the ability to analyze new materials and manufacturing processes. The technical approach used is cost-effective, non-destructive and provides the anisotropic elastic properties of the grains and with that, the grain orientation.


One of the outcomes of this work is the ability to quantify the anisotropic linear elastic behavior of solids through a non-destructive approach. The approach is based on iterative inverse algorithms using the framework of finite element discretization schemes. The approach enables the ability to map the anisotropic linear elastic parameter distributions with high accuracy. Overall, the proposed approach has potential to characterize the anisotropic mechanical behavior of polymer-based materials or tissues for pathology.


A second outcome of the project is the creation of an inverse algorithm for the characterization of hyper-elastic material properties which takes into consideration unknown conditions on a part of the boundary; this is an advancement on prior methods that assumed fully known boundary conditions. The method was tested on several examples. In all the examples, the obtained results are verified and it is observed that the results are satisfactory and reliable.Being able to determine material properties with unknown boundary conditions is important in engineering and health applications. 


An additional outcome that directly addresses the primary project goals is the demonstrated feasibility to recover the stiffness distribution of a three-dimensional heterogeneous sample using measured surface displacements and inverse algorithms without making any assumptions about local homogeneities and the stiffness distribution. The method recovers the shear modulus values in the inclusions and background well. The method reveals the shape of the inclusion clearly.


The final key outcome of this project is the first-time creation of a novel tomography approach based on the mechanics of solids. It utilizes the equations of equilibrium in an optimization framework to control the ill-posed nature of these problems. Measured signals are deformation fields obtained from a digital image correlation system with photo cameras. This work demonstrates the potential of mechanics based tomography on a composite silicone material. The approach has been experimentally validated. 


The broader impacts of this work include specific impact on the field of engineering mechanics as well as new results that can be extended to direct societal impact. Outcomes of this work include new fundamental results toward novel and cost-effective means to map residual stresses destructively at the micro-scale and non-destructively at the macroscale. Knowing residual stresses enables a better understanding of the inherent introduction of residual stresses from specific manufacturing processes. Extending to potential direct societal impact, the outcomes of this work build a foundation for future applications in comparisons of engineered tissue with actual human tissue for health applications. Future applications in breast cancer screenings are possible based on an understanding of interior breast tissue morphology from surface screenings. Another long-term application of the outcomes of this work is a non-destructive testing tool for civil engineering structures such as bridges.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/27/2022
Modified by: Daniel A Mcadams
